title: Synthetic Recap
body:
INDIANAPOLIS — On a night when the box score told a story of historic proportions, one name echoed throughout Market Square Arena: Reggie Miller.

The Indiana Pacers’ sharpshooter delivered a performance for the ages, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 42 points to single-handedly dismantle the visiting Toronto Raptors, 111-92. While the final score indicated a comfortable Pacers victory, this was not a team win; it was a one-man spectacle.

From the opening tip, Miller was uncontainable. He orchestrated a breathtaking shooting clinic, connecting on 12 of his 22 field goal attempts with a ruthless efficiency. But it was from beyond the arc where he authored his masterpiece, draining a staggering six three-pointers. Each long-range bomb seemed to suck the life from the Raptors, a relentless assault that built an insurmountable lead.

Even when fouled, there was no respite. Miller was a perfect 12-for-12 from the charity stripe, a testament to his flawless focus and unshakable confidence on this record-setting night. His 42 points weren't just a number; they were a declaration, a virtuoso performance that carved up the defense in every way imaginable.

The Raptors, led by 18 points from Walt Williams, had no answer. They were merely witnesses to a piece of NBA history unfolding before them. The Pacers' supporting cast, including 17 points from Derrick McKey, played their roles perfectly, feeding the hot hand and watching the maestro work.

When the final horn sounded, the record was his. Miller’s 42-point eruption was not just a career milestone; it was a legendary chapter cemented in Pacers lore, a night where one superstar transcended the game and left an entire arena, and a defeated opponent, in awe.
